awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Investigating the Linkage Among Environment, Subsistence, and Work Allocation
awd_abstract_narration:
Explaining how humans adapt to climate change and population growth remain central research questions in anthropology and are relevant to contemporary issues. About fourteen thousand years ago, ancestral Native Americans first entered the Great Basin of North America, where they encountered a landscape dominated by large inland lakes and marshes. Although the climate was generally cooler and wetter than today, it was highly variable and experienced dramatic shifts associated with the transition from the Pleistocene to Holocene epochs. Nonetheless, early Native Americans developed a stable adaptation, characterized by a flexible technology and subsistence base, and high mobility that persevered over the ensuing six millennia, but dramatically reorganized with the onset of extreme aridity about 8,000 years ago. Understanding how these first Americans made a living, interacted with one another, and adapted to climatic change is critical to explaining the colonization of the Americas, and how humans adapt to changing environments more generally. The researchers believe that a cooperative organization of labor by gender was the central feature of this adaptation. This work will develop and validate a general model of human adaptation and a predictive model of archaeological site location useful in other academic research and public lands cultural resource management. It will also garner primary data on past climatic and vegetation change that will contribute broadly to understanding of environmental variability in the western United States. In addition to supporting undergraduate and graduate student education, this project will disseminate research findings to the public through coverage from public broadcasting and major events at regional museums. 

It is challenging to recover and interpret archaeological evidence of human responses to past climate change from ancient contexts significantly different from modern environments. Gathering the necessary data requires well-grounded theoretical expectations both about where people likely lived and where evidence of their activities has survived. This project adopts such a research strategy by coupling behavioral and geomorphological models to identify and recover evidence of past human habitation along these ancient lake and marsh habitats. This project combines theoretical predictions from behavioral ecology about women?s and men?s subsistence strategies, with sophisticated geomorphological models to predict where they are likely to be preserved in datable buried deposits. Focused on explaining the pre-9,000 year old archaeology of Grass Valley, Nevada, this project entails targeted archaeological field investigations, generating paleoenvironmental reconstructions from pollen profiles and packrat middens, and conducting geochemical explorations of local fine-grained volcanic toolstone quarries. Combined, these data will allow systematic investigation of how early Native Americans adapted to the Pleistocene Great Basin through a period of changing climate. The central theoretical and methodological models developed and tested in the project are generalizable to other contexts, providing a framework to explain processes of human colonization and adaptation around the world.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project convened an interdisciplinary team of archaeologists, geomorphologists, and paleoecologists to investigate the lifeways of the earliest inhabitants of the central Great Basin in what is today central Nevada. Results show that these populations relied on wetland habitats associated with Pleistocene-aged closed rainfed (pluvial) lakes. Based on the locations of their campsites relative to our reconstruction of lakeshore environments, animal bones recovered from excavations, and inferences to more recent hunter-gatherer societies, we suggest they  made a living by hunting waterfowl, intercepting migrating deer, and harvesting profitable plant resources. Analysis of excavated material shows they often made tools from locally available volcanic rocks (dacite), the source of which was documented as a part of this project. They also sustained social connections across vast distances, evident from other rarer tools made from sourceable volcanic glass (obsidian), imported from as far away as California, Utah, Idaho and southern Nevada. Radiocarbon dates on cultural material, paired with pollen-derived environmental reconstructions from a sedimentary core reveal that these population lived through the greatest period of climate change experienced by any human in North America, across the terminal Pleistocene to Holocene transition, which led to the desiccation of pluvial lakes and ultimately ended their unique adaptation. Dust blowing from these dry lake beds covered much of the material they left behind, making it difficult to find intact campsite deposits today.

 

Intellectual Merit. This project made three major contributions to advance knowledge. First, through intensive and systematic investigations within a bounded project area, this work revealed a wealth of information about rare and understudied adaptations associated with terminal Pleistocene to early Holocene populations living at open-air shoreline camps around small pluvial lakes. This includes the first site securely dated to this early period of human occupation in the area. Second, we developed a systematic and generalizable approach that couples theoretically-informed predictions about past adaptations with empirically-derived estimates of landform ages and on-the-ground pedestrian survey to efficiently identify rare archaeological material. Third, our results offer an opportunity to explore how local adaptations and regional connectivity vary as a function of climate-driven changes in the distribution of specific habitats and resources.

 

Broader Impacts. This project had three specific societal outcomes. First, our systematic and generalizable approach to predict undiscovered locations of rare archaeological sites will enable more efficient management of cultural resources on federal land. Second, this project provided on-the-job training for students from diverse backgrounds at the PhD., masters, and bachelors level, which is needed to secure employment as archaeologists in private and government sectors. Moreover, NSF support of this project enabled underrepresented minority and underprivileged students to affordably attend an archaeological field school, which is crucial training for undergraduate students pursuing careers in archaeology  Finally, through public dissemination of the results, this project aims to enhance appreciation of deep Indigenous history across the region. 


Last Modified: 12/02/2021
Modified by: Brian F Codding
